segment.source: Hard Drives and Partitions
segment.target: Hard Drives and Partitions

segment.source: Hard Drives and Partitions
segment.target: Hard Drives and Partitions

segment.source: Hard Drives and Partitions
segment.target: Hard Drives and Partitions

segment.source: In this section, you will learn methods to deploy Windows to different drives, including hard drives, solid-state drives (SSDs), or virtual hard drives (VHDs).
segment.target: In this section, you will learn methods to deploy Windows to different drives, including hard drives, solid-state drives (SSDs), or virtual hard drives (VHDs).

segment.source: You will also learn about factors that you must consider when you deploy Windows.
segment.target: You will also learn about factors that you must consider when you deploy Windows.

segment.source: What's new in Windows 10
segment.target: What's new in Windows 10

segment.source: Use Compact OS and single-sourcing to save more space on the hard drive: Compact OS, single-sourcing, and image optimization.
segment.target: Use Compact OS and single-sourcing to save more space on the hard drive: Compact OS, single-sourcing, and image optimization.

segment.source: Use the FFU image format to apply images faster to your devices: Deploy Windows using Full Flash Update (FFU)
segment.target: Use the FFU image format to apply images faster to your devices: Deploy Windows using Full Flash Update (FFU)

segment.source: In Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education), we've changed the partition layout.
segment.target: In Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education), we've changed the partition layout.

segment.source: While we still use a separate recovery tools image, Windows no longer needs a separate full-system recovery image to use push-button reset features.
segment.target: While we still use a separate recovery tools image, Windows no longer needs a separate full-system recovery image to use push-button reset features.

segment.source: This can save several GB of drive space.
segment.target: This can save several GB of drive space.

segment.source: We now recommend that you place the Windows recovery tools partition immediately after the Windows partition.
segment.target: We now recommend that you place the Windows recovery tools partition immediately after the Windows partition.

segment.source: This allows Windows to modify and recreate the partition later if future updates require a larger recovery image.
segment.target: This allows Windows to modify and recreate the partition later if future updates require a larger recovery image.

segment.source: If you use scripts to deploy Windows, check out the new sample scripts we've created for different device firmware types (the newer UEFI-based BIOS, or the legacy BIOS).
segment.target: If you use scripts to deploy Windows, check out the new sample scripts we've created for different device firmware types (the newer UEFI-based BIOS, or the legacy BIOS).

segment.source: To learn more, see UEFI/GPT-based hard drive partitions and BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions.
segment.target: To learn more, see UEFI/GPT-based hard drive partitions and BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions.

segment.source: It's no longer necessary to run the Windows System Assessment Tests (WinSAT) on SSD drives.
segment.target: It's no longer necessary to run the Windows System Assessment Tests (WinSAT) on SSD drives.

segment.source: Windows detects SSD drives and tunes itself accordingly.
segment.target: Windows detects SSD drives and tunes itself accordingly.

segment.source: On UEFI/GPT-based drives, we've reduced the recommended size of the MSR partition from 128MB to 16MB.
segment.target: On UEFI/GPT-based drives, we've reduced the recommended size of the MSR partition from 128MB to 16MB.

segment.source: Drive types
segment.target: Drive types

segment.source: You can install Windows to a hard drive, such as a hard disk drive or a solid-state drive.
segment.target: You can install Windows to a hard drive, such as a hard disk drive or a solid-state drive.

segment.source: For additional security, you can use hard drives that the factory has pre-encrypted.
segment.target: For additional security, you can use hard drives that the factory has pre-encrypted.

segment.source: A single computer may contain multiple drives.
segment.target: A single computer may contain multiple drives.

segment.source: Solid-state drives
segment.target: Solid-state drives

segment.source: A solid-state drive (SSD) is a hard drive that uses solid-state memory to store persistent data.
segment.target: A solid-state drive (SSD) is a hard drive that uses solid-state memory to store persistent data.

segment.source: An SSD must have a minimum of 16 gigabytes (GB) of space to install Windows.
segment.target: An SSD must have a minimum of 16 gigabytes (GB) of space to install Windows.

segment.source: For more information about drive space and RAM considerations, see Compact OS, single-sourcing, and image optimization.
segment.target: For more information about drive space and RAM considerations, see Compact OS, single-sourcing, and image optimization.

segment.source: Note It's no longer necessary to run the Windows System Assessment Tests (WinSAT) on SSD drives.
segment.target: Note It's no longer necessary to run the Windows System Assessment Tests (WinSAT) on SSD drives.

segment.source: Windows now detects SSD drives and will tune itself accordingly.
segment.target: Windows now detects SSD drives and will tune itself accordingly.

segment.source: Advanced format drives
segment.target: Advanced format drives

segment.source: You can use some Advanced Format Drives to provide additional drive space.
segment.target: You can use some Advanced Format Drives to provide additional drive space.

segment.source: Advanced Format 512 emulation (512e) drives are supported on either BIOS-based or UEFI-based computers.
segment.target: Advanced Format 512 emulation (512e) drives are supported on either BIOS-based or UEFI-based computers.

segment.source: Advanced Format 4K Native (4Kn) drives are supported on UEFI-based computers only.
segment.target: Advanced Format 4K Native (4Kn) drives are supported on UEFI-based computers only.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: For Advanced Format 4K Native drives (4-KB-per-sector) drives, the minimum partition size is 260 MB, due to a limitation of the FAT32 file format.
segment.target: For Advanced Format 4K Native drives (4-KB-per-sector) drives, the minimum partition size is 260 MB, due to a limitation of the FAT32 file format.

segment.source: The minimum partition size of FAT32 drives is calculated as sector size (4KB) x 65527 = 256 MB.
segment.target: The minimum partition size of FAT32 drives is calculated as sector size (4KB) x 65527 = 256 MB.

segment.source: For more information, see Configure UEFI/GPT-Based Hard Drive Partitions.
segment.target: For more information, see Configure UEFI/GPT-Based Hard Drive Partitions.

segment.source: Factory-encrypted hard drives
segment.target: Factory-encrypted hard drives

segment.source: To help protect your deployment environment, you can use a factory pre-encrypted hard drive to prevent unauthorized access before you install Windows or any other software.
segment.target: To help protect your deployment environment, you can use a factory pre-encrypted hard drive to prevent unauthorized access before you install Windows or any other software.

segment.source: For more information, see Factory Encrypted Drives.
segment.target: For more information, see Factory Encrypted Drives.

segment.source: Multiple hard drives
segment.target: Multiple hard drives

segment.source: If you install Windows on a device that has multiple hard drives, you can use the disk location path to make sure that your images are applied to the intended drives.
segment.target: If you install Windows on a device that has multiple hard drives, you can use the disk location path to make sure that your images are applied to the intended drives.

segment.source: To do this, use the command to select each drive.
segment.target: To do this, use the command to select each drive.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The system drive might not appear as disk 0 in the DiskPart tool.
segment.target: The system drive might not appear as disk 0 in the DiskPart tool.

segment.source: The system might assign different numbers to drives when you reboot.
segment.target: The system might assign different numbers to drives when you reboot.

segment.source: Different computers that have the same drive configuration can have different disk numbers.
segment.target: Different computers that have the same drive configuration can have different disk numbers.

segment.source: To learn more, see Configure Multiple Hard Drives and Hard Disk Location Path Format.
segment.target: To learn more, see Configure Multiple Hard Drives and Hard Disk Location Path Format.

segment.source: Partitions
segment.target: Partitions

segment.source: You can divide your hard drive into multiple partitions.
segment.target: You can divide your hard drive into multiple partitions.

segment.source: You can create separate system, recovery, Windows, or data partitions.
segment.target: You can create separate system, recovery, Windows, or data partitions.

segment.source: To enhance the security of the Windows partition or a data partition, you can use BitLocker to encrypt the partition.
segment.target: To enhance the security of the Windows partition or a data partition, you can use BitLocker to encrypt the partition.

segment.source: For more information, see BitLocker Drive Encryption.
segment.target: For more information, see BitLocker Drive Encryption.

segment.source: The partition types must match the firmware of the computer.
segment.target: The partition types must match the firmware of the computer.

segment.source: You can install Windows on hard drives that are based on any of the following types of firmware:
segment.target: You can install Windows on hard drives that are based on any of the following types of firmware:

segment.source: Basic Input/Output System (BIOS).
segment.target: Basic Input/Output System (BIOS).

segment.source: Uses the Master Boot Record (MBR) partition structure.
segment.target: Uses the Master Boot Record (MBR) partition structure.

segment.source: Extensible Firmware Interface (EFI) (Class 1): Uses the GUID Partition Table (GPT) partition structure.
segment.target: Extensible Firmware Interface (EFI) (Class 1): Uses the GUID Partition Table (GPT) partition structure.

segment.source: Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) Class 2: Uses the GPT partition structure.
segment.target: Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) Class 2: Uses the GPT partition structure.

segment.source: Also includes a compatibility support module (CSM) that enables you to use BIOS functions, including the MBR partition structure.
segment.target: Also includes a compatibility support module (CSM) that enables you to use BIOS functions, including the MBR partition structure.

segment.source: This module can be enabled or disabled in the firmware.
segment.target: This module can be enabled or disabled in the firmware.

segment.source: Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) Class 3: Uses the GPT partition structure.
segment.target: Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) Class 3: Uses the GPT partition structure.

segment.source: To determine your system type, consult your hardware manufacturer.
segment.target: To determine your system type, consult your hardware manufacturer.

segment.source: System and utility partitions
segment.target: System and utility partitions

segment.source: A system partition is a partition that contains the hardware-specific files that are needed to load Windows.
segment.target: A system partition is a partition that contains the hardware-specific files that are needed to load Windows.

segment.source: By default, during Windows Setup, Windows stores these hardware-specific files in a separate partition.
segment.target: By default, during Windows Setup, Windows stores these hardware-specific files in a separate partition.

segment.source: This enables the computer to use the following:
segment.target: This enables the computer to use the following:

segment.source: Security tools.
segment.target: Security tools.

segment.source: Some security tools, such as BitLocker, require a separate system partition.
segment.target: Some security tools, such as BitLocker, require a separate system partition.

segment.source: Recovery tools.
segment.target: Recovery tools.

segment.source: Some recovery tools, such as Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE), require a separate system partition.
segment.target: Some recovery tools, such as Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE), require a separate system partition.

segment.source: Multiple operating systems.
segment.target: Multiple operating systems.

segment.source: If a computer has multiple operating systems, such as Windows 10 for desktop editions and Windows 7, the computer displays a list of operating systems.
segment.target: If a computer has multiple operating systems, such as Windows 10 for desktop editions and Windows 7, the computer displays a list of operating systems.

segment.source: The user can then select which operating system to boot.
segment.target: The user can then select which operating system to boot.

segment.source: When the system boot files are on a separate partition, it is easier to remove a Windows partition or replace the partition with a new copy of Windows.
segment.target: When the system boot files are on a separate partition, it is easier to remove a Windows partition or replace the partition with a new copy of Windows.

segment.source: We recommend adding system utility partitions before the Windows partition, because in the event that a full-system recovery is needed, this partition order helps to prevent the recovery tools from overwriting the system and utility partitions.
segment.target: We recommend adding system utility partitions before the Windows partition, because in the event that a full-system recovery is needed, this partition order helps to prevent the recovery tools from overwriting the system and utility partitions.

segment.source: For information about how to configure system partitions while you apply images, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.
segment.target: For information about how to configure system partitions while you apply images, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.

segment.source: Microsoft reserved partition (MSR)
segment.target: Microsoft reserved partition (MSR)

segment.source: The MSR is used on UEFI/GPT systems, to support software components that formerly used hidden sectors.
segment.target: The MSR is used on UEFI/GPT systems, to support software components that formerly used hidden sectors.

segment.source: For more information about configuring MSR partitions, see Configure UEFI/GPT-Based Hard Drive Partitions.
segment.target: For more information about configuring MSR partitions, see Configure UEFI/GPT-Based Hard Drive Partitions.

segment.source: For more information about MSR partitions, see Windows and GPT FAQ
segment.target: For more information about MSR partitions, see Windows and GPT FAQ

segment.source: Recovery partitions
segment.target: Recovery partitions

segment.source: We recommend adding a separate partition for the Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE) at the end of the hard drive.
segment.target: We recommend adding a separate partition for the Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE) at the end of the hard drive.

segment.source: With this partition order, if future updates require adding to or replacing the Windows RE tools partition, Windows will be able to manage the partition size automatically.
segment.target: With this partition order, if future updates require adding to or replacing the Windows RE tools partition, Windows will be able to manage the partition size automatically.

segment.source: For BIOS/MBR-based systems, it's still possible to combine the Windows RE tools partition with the system partition.
segment.target: For BIOS/MBR-based systems, it's still possible to combine the Windows RE tools partition with the system partition.

segment.source: To save drive space, consider creating logical partitions to get around the four-partition limit.
segment.target: To save drive space, consider creating logical partitions to get around the four-partition limit.

segment.source: For more info, see Configure more than four partitions on a BIOS/MBR-based hard disk.
segment.target: For more info, see Configure more than four partitions on a BIOS/MBR-based hard disk.

segment.source: For Windows 10 for desktop editions, it's no longer necessary to create and maintain a separate full-system recovery image.
segment.target: For Windows 10 for desktop editions, it's no longer necessary to create and maintain a separate full-system recovery image.

segment.source: Windows can perform a refresh or reset using built-in tools.
segment.target: Windows can perform a refresh or reset using built-in tools.

segment.source: Data partitions
segment.target: Data partitions

segment.source: A data partition is a partition that stores user data.
segment.target: A data partition is a partition that stores user data.

segment.source: A separate data partition can enable easier maintenance for situations where either the primary operating system is likely to be replaced, or when multiple operating systems exist on the same device, such as Windows 10 and Windows 7.
segment.target: A separate data partition can enable easier maintenance for situations where either the primary operating system is likely to be replaced, or when multiple operating systems exist on the same device, such as Windows 10 and Windows 7.

segment.source: When a device has multiple hard drives, a data partition may be stored on another drive.
segment.target: When a device has multiple hard drives, a data partition may be stored on another drive.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: For typical single-drive configurations, we do not recommend that you use a separate data partition.
segment.target: For typical single-drive configurations, we do not recommend that you use a separate data partition.

segment.source: There are two main reasons:
segment.target: There are two main reasons:

segment.source: The partition may not automatically protect data that is stored outside the user profile folders.
segment.target: The partition may not automatically protect data that is stored outside the user profile folders.

segment.source: For example, a guest user might have access to files in an unprotected data partition.
segment.target: For example, a guest user might have access to files in an unprotected data partition.

segment.source: If you change the default location of the user profile folders to any volume other than the system volume, you cannot service your image.
segment.target: If you change the default location of the user profile folders to any volume other than the system volume, you cannot service your image.

segment.source: The computer may not apply updates, fixes, or service packs to the installation.
segment.target: The computer may not apply updates, fixes, or service packs to the installation.

segment.source: For a list of known issues related to changing the default folder locations, see Description of known issues with the FolderLocation settings.
segment.target: For a list of known issues related to changing the default folder locations, see Description of known issues with the FolderLocation settings.

segment.target: See also
